title: Create /cub meta-skill for in-session discovery

task.title: Create /cub meta-skill for in-session discovery
task.description:
Users inside a harness session need to discover what cub skills are available. A `/cub` meta-skill lists available skills, common commands, and current project status.

**Implementation Steps:**
1. Create `.claude/commands/cub.md` as the meta-skill
2. Include: list of available `/cub:*` skills with one-line descriptions
3. Include: common `cub` CLI commands runnable via Bash (task ready, status, run)
4. Include: brief explanation of modes (conversational, structured, supervised, autonomous)
5. Include: dynamic project state (injected via template variables or by running `cub status`)

**Files:** .claude/commands/cub.md

commits.message: task(cub-b1f.1): Create /cub meta-skill for in-session discovery

outcome.approach: The task was completed by first studying existing cub skills and CLI documentation to understand the project's structure and conventions, then creating a comprehensive meta-skill that serves as a discovery hub. The implementation dynamically references `cub status` for real-time project metrics while providing organized lists of available skills, common commands, and explanations of execution modes.
decisions: Organized the meta-skill into logical sections (skills, CLI commands, modes, status) rather than a flat list to aid discoverability
Included cost-efficiency guidance for model selection to help users make informed decisions about which skills to use
Made the project status dynamic by instructing users to run `cub status` rather than hardcoding static information
Followed existing skill documentation patterns and style to ensure consistency with the rest of the cub ecosystem
Included safety/isolation information (sandbox and worktree options) to help users understand execution boundaries
lessons_learned: Meta-documentation skills are most useful when they organize information hierarchically and include both "what" (list of skills) and "why" (execution modes, cost guidance)
Referencing dynamic commands (like `cub status`) in documentation makes the skill more maintainable than hardcoding project state
For discovery-focused tools, including quick-start examples and workflow patterns significantly increases usability beyond just listing available options
Pre-existing code issues in feedback loops shouldn't block documentation-only changes—focus on validating that the new content itself is correct
